In discussing Lord Cromer’s speech, “A1 Moayad” remarks that the better the reiar tions between Abdeen and Buckingham Palace, the better for Egypt, and that the attitude of the extremists, whose idea of patriotism is a systematic opposition to all that has to do with theV Iccupation, is brainless and even opposed to the principles of the Koran. With Lord Cromer’s four conditions the “Moayad” expresses its agreement subject to one or two reservations. While admitting that a di- rect control of Egyptian afiairs by Parliament would injure Egypt, it remarks that Parlia- ment must never lose its control of what are, after all, its agents in Egypt,and must be able to check any abuse of , their powers. In this connection., it is earnestly to be desired that some means existed of bringing the Egyptian point of view before Parliament as clearly as Lord Cromer’s point of view is set forth in the Blue-books. The caution in the introduction of Western ideas must not be exaggerated, for Egypt has made great strides, and finally, while there is no question of Lord Cromer’s sincere devotion to the good of Egypt, many of his projects have been diverted from their end by those charged to carry them out. "A1 Lewa” expresses its disagreement with “A1 Moayad’s” views. Opposition to the British Occupation is an absolute necessity, and it is strange that “A1 Moayad,"‘after 14 years in opposition, should abandon its policy and support Lord Cromer’s views. The opponents of the Occupation are the only veritable patri- ots. If Lord Cromer’s wishes for the welfare of the Egyptian people are sincere, he should permit them to occupy many of the important positions now reserved for Englishmen, and reduce the expenses caused by the Occupation. , The Egyptians were the first civilised race in the history of the world and are to-day as capable of assimilating modern civilisation as the Japanese or the English themselves. The dangers to which antomobilists and car- riage drivers expose themselves are most serious, as with this exaggerated speed it is certain that more often than not the watch- men have hardly time to signal to them before they are on the line. Consequently, we are asked by the company to appeal to the public, when driving over these crossings, to slacken speed in order to avoid any chance of accident. ( From a Correspondent. ) i Beyrout, July 2.- ( For over three decades the Syrian Protestant 1 College stood, as it were, on an eminence as a 1 jeaoonW knowledge shedding a growing light < on Syria, and in its - later phases of develop- ‘ ment it has" plainly become odo of the mtot - potent educational factors in the Near East. 1 One has but to glance at the latest edition of , ’ its prospectuses, of Which a judicious distribu- 1 tion is annually made, to realise the magnitude 1 of its infiuen o and the soope of its field of action. This magnifioent institution reornits < its army,of about • 700 students from various 1 countries. Its radios of power extends from < Armenia in the East to Greeoe and the Etonian 1 sles in the West, and from Asi/Minor in -the • North down to Egypt in the South. But its ] influence has been mostly felt in Egypt, di- < reotly through the preponderant numbhr <Sf < seekers for knowledge that the Land of"' the Pharaohs has always supplied, and indireotly ’ but uo less mightily through the Syrian * settlers who constitute a strong ' intellectual 1 element in Egyptian life, and who, under the 1 strong, capable, and jndioions guidance of 1 British rulers, are contributing largely to the 1 progress of the country. Therefore any event 1 of public character in this birthplace of learn- 1 ing should not fail to appeal to the interest of 1 the readers of the “Gazette.” The commencement exercises this year 1 began on Saturday, 24th June, ten days earlier than the usual and traditional time. This has been determined by the early arrival of the mperial Medical Commission from Constan- 1 tinople. Although the exercises commenced on Saturday yet they may be considered to have been publicly inaugurated by the Baccalaureate service on Snnday, when President Howard Bliss delivered his annual valedictory and exhortatory address to the medical and phar- maceutical graduates: The scene was, as it may easily be imagined, one calonlated to oaf! Forth deep and stirring emotions and inspire thoughts of the noblest kind, and the young ; ^resident’s fiery eloquence rose splendidly to the occasion. The meeting was well attended by students and many of the public. The bless- ing was fitly given by the old President Eme- ritus, whose appearance in pnblio functions at the college is still inspiring and recalls to the ieart» of older students happy memories of the godd old dayB. The exercises closed on Wednesday with the ceremony of the distribution of prizes and diplomas. The. principal afid striking •'feature of that day wds the processional march. At Ada Dodge Hall the procession, consisting of the old graduates, the faculty, and the staff of teachers, formed, and proceeded to the Memorial Hall at 3.30 p m. preceded by the American Consol and the Imperial Medical Commission. The President and members of the Faculty wore their‘academic gowns, and as it marched forth with measured step and took .ita'Seats on the platform in the Memorial HalL the procession presented a sight of unusual solemnity. The closing event was a delightful entertain- ment on Wednesday evening at the President’s, Marquand House, wound up by a series of hilarious and comic songs, lustily sung by a part of the American staff of teachers. The entertainment is given principally in honor of the Imperial Medical Commission, composed this year of General Mahmoud Hakki Pasha, a vejy distinguished officer, Colonel Ahmed -p'ehmi Bey, and Major Esoret Roushen Bey. The reception was held in the president’s class-room, a hall of specious dimensions, but which, owing to the large crowd, could afford only standing room. This, coupled with the torrid heat of June, made it particularly uncomfortable to the invites, and called forth suggestions from some of them for an enlarge- ment of the hall, which would not be inad- visable considering the growing importance of the'college. But the welcome was so hearty, and there was such a general air of conviviality, that the heat and other little* discomforts were forgotten. Besides, to those blessed with a sense of humour and that rare power of self- detachment, there was afforded a rich fund of/amusement by the presentation of the myites to the Imperial Commission. This 3Anguished body was victimised by a pre- tation of almost all the large crowd of Quests, and for about half an honr there was something like a pantomimic show of a fi'e of ladies and gedtlemen coming forward with different degrees of grace and awkwardness to -hake hands with^ the three commissioners, who cut carious figures, repeating with automatic sameness the stiff, jerky, and deep German how in reply to each introduction. After the ordeal they withdrew to the cooler reoesses of the garden on whioh the hall opens, to indulge in timely refreshments and the necessary accompaniment of the fragrant weed. These entertainments form a cheerful ending for fhe graduates of a year of hard study, wakeful anxieties, and stirring emo- tions, and no donbt they-procure the hospi- table President and his charming wife many a farewell word of blessing from the grateful pupils who are to face the hard realities of life. I had almost forgotten to add that 28 medi- cal students were presented to the Commis- sion for the final examination. Of these one did not oomplete his examination, one failed to pass, 36 took the oath of office before the commission and reoeived their oollege diplomas. Their Turkish diplomas will be sent to them later. Nine pharmacy students were presented to the commissioners lor final examination. 0:' 1 these *U pasted pmd took the oath and reoeiy- M diplomas. Now that the summer has began in earnest, many dwellers in inland towns will be thinking of making a move soon to' some favored spot by the seaside where the invigorating ocean : breezes will once more brace the jaded residents of the interior. I very tfmch doubt whether the frequenters of this little place, which springs into life with the advent of the great heat, would seek to qualify its attractions by comparison with those offered elsewhere, say at Ramleh o/ Port Said, but I do not hesitate to say that it possesses a charm of its own, and I am not surprised when I discern the same familiar faces there^sar after year. * * The season proper at this Egyptian Margate, if I may term it so, does- not commence in earnest until the middle of July, and is in fall swing until about the end of September, So that the hotel-keepers and others who minister to the wants of the strangers have, in a sense, to make My while the sun shines, although, con- sidering the shortness of the season, no one can say that the prices charged are exor- bitant The majority of the visitors are Levantines and Egyptians, leavened by a fair number of Europeans of all the nationalities that inhabit this country.
